div.p: 1. My time begins to be so much and so necessarily, and so much occupied in preparations and arrangements for my departure, that I have scarcely any left for writing at my business here, or attendance at my Office— I did however write something this day— The children were with me at my Office this afternoon. In the Evening I went with my wife, to a party at Mr: S. A. Otis’s, which I was surprized to find a very large party— We left them early in the Evening.

div.p: 2. I walk’d to Cambridge this morning; and read my Lecture 25. at 10 O’Clock— Attended the Declamation at 2. dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Return’d to Boston in the Stage— A North-East Storm of Rain was somewhat troublesome, and has given us all severe colds— I spent an hour this morning at Mr: Holmes’s—returned him the papers of the historical Society, which he had sent me for examination; and looked over some others.

3. I was called up in the middle of the Night, to our second boy, John, who was seized with one of those violent hoarse turns, which have several times before, alarmed us for him— We gave him a strong emetic which operated, not without difficulty— I then returned to bed, and found him this morning better— The infant child has also an excessive cold— The Night and all the first part of this day were very stormy— The tides at noon so high that they overflowed some of the wharves— Mr: Sheldon called this morning to see us—here on a short visit from Washington— I called on Mr: Shaw, and left my papers with him— Took much pains to find a vessel bound to Alexandria, to send my trunk, and a box of books for the Congress library— But without success— The remainder of the day I was at home— I was obliged to dismiss our man-servant again this morning; and am once more without any.

4. My father’s Carriage this morning unexpectedly came in from Quincy to take us out— And we all went out together; my wife, the three children and myself. We got there just before dinner— The weather was however stormy, all the latter part of the day— Captn: Beale and Mr: Wainwright came in this Evening.

5. I was up the greatest part of the Night, and entirely deprived of rest— My wife and infant child being both very unwell with Colds—and I have been unable to overcome an excessive anxiety on such occasions— We returned this morning to Boston; leaving our son John at Quincy, to spend the Winter at Mrs: Cranch’s. John Smith came in to Boston with us, and return’d to Quincy after dinner. I was so much fatigued with the watching of last night, and with drowsiness, that I could not finish my lecture— Some part of it however I did write.— By invitation of Mr: Coolidge I spent the Evening and supp’d with him, and the Trustees of the humane Society.— The Company broke up about 11. O’Clock.

6. I called this Morning on Mr: Jackson the College Treasurer; but did not see him— Called also upon Governor Sullivan to enquire if he had any public business for Washington— He talk’d of the unsettled Eastern line, and of the prospects of War with England— At 11. O’Clock, a meeting was held of the Directors of Neponsit Bridge, at my Office—the Officers of the last year were rechosen, and a dividend declared— I spoke to Mr: T. Greenleaf respecting the papers of the late Governor Adams; and he promis’d that we should have some of them for the historical Society.— This afternoon I finished my Lecture 26.— John Smith came in from Quincy, to go to-morrow morning in the Stage to Albany— His mother, brother and Sister, expect to go the next week, or week after.

7. John Smith went at 5 this morning for Albany— I am now so much occupied in making preparation for our Journey and Voyage to Washington, that I can write no more for my lectures, and am compelled to suspend almost all reading and writing— Dr: Park, Mr: Shaw, Mr: J. Gardner, and Mr: Everett dined with us— My brother was in town, this morning; but return’d at Night, to Quincy.— In the Evening the club was at Mr: Cobb’s— We had some conversation respecting the Comet, which continues to appear since the Nights have become again serene. Mr: Kendall, was also there— And has spent some time at Dighton, where he has taken an exact painting of the famous rock bearing an inscription; which he shewed us last Evening.— I found Charlotte Welsh with Mrs: Adams, when I came home— She spends the Night here.

8. Employed all the morning and Evening in preparations for our own departure, and for sending George to Mrs: Peabody, at Atkinson— Dined with Mr: Edward Gray— Mr Emerson, Mr: Buckminster, Mr: W. Sullivan, Mr: Rowe, Mr: F. Channing, and Mr: Shaw dined with us— And Mr: John Gray— Home early wrote to Mrs: Peabody, on account of George— Walk’d with my wife and George a few minutes in the Mall; to shew them the Comet.— Shaw called with a letter and parcel for Mr: Harrod at Haverhill, to go by George— I called on a Mr: Kimball Carleton, who I found by the Stage Books was going to Haverhill to-morrow; and I requested him to take care of George on the road; which he promised.

div.p: 9. Before five this morning the Haverhill Stage called for George, but he was so unwell, that after some hesitation we thought it best to postpone sending him untill Monday. I followed the Stage, with him to the Stage-Office; but it was gone just as we arrived there— I walk’d up to Cambridge, and at 10. O’Clock delivered my Lecture 26. I had promised to dine with Mr: Holmes, but finding the pressure of affairs to settle so great on this last day before my departure, I concluded to return this morning to Boston, without waiting for the Declamation— I called at the President’s, and informed him of my intention to go to-morrow.— Returning to Boston, Mr: T. English took me up with him in his Chair; and landed me near my Office in Court-Street— I was engaged in disposing of our affairs and making our arrangements untill near four O’Clock before we dined— My Sister’s son William was in town, and dined with us. My brother was also in town, and settled accounts with me— He took George out with him to Quincy, to remain there untill Sunday Evening, when he is to return here, and be ready to go in the Stage, on Monday— Mr: De Grand and Mr Shaw were here this Evening— We finished our preparations, to be ready for the Providence Stage. Dr: Welsh also was here.

10. At 8. O’Clock we took the Providence Stage, and after an easy and pleasant days ride, arrived at Ammidon’s tavern about 6 in the Evening— We dined at Hatch’s in Attleborough— We found as fellow Passengers in the Stage, Mr: Cook and Mr: Ilsley two members of Congress from the District of Maine, and four other Gentlemen— We found at Providence two Packets ready to sail for New-York to-morrow morning; the Polly Captain Brown, and the Eliza Captain Currie; we concluded to embark with the latter; and went on board the Packet to examine the accommodations.

11. The Packet had drop’d down from the wharf early this morning, and after breakfast we embarked from the lower wharf, to which we proceeded in a Hackney Coach— Mr: Ilsley and Mr: Cook, with one other of our fellow-passengers in the Stage came on board with us; and we found several other passengers on board, among whom were a Mr: Butler, and Mr: Easton, a gentleman with whom Mrs: Adams came from New-York to Boston in August last year— The weather was so totally calm the whole of this day that we lay at Anchor about a mile below Providence through the day— Mr: Cook and Mr: Butler went on shore this afternoon—but return’d at the beginning of the Evening— The Captain also went on Shore in pursuit of other passengers, and did not return this Night.

12. The total calm continued the whole Night, and we remained at anchor— This morning however, about 8 o’clock came on board the Captain with three additional passengers; Mr: and Mrs: Gamage, and a Mr: Prentiss I had some difficulty in maintaining the right to one of the after Cabins which we had taken; but did however secure it. There was through the whole day scarcely wind enough at any time to fill our sails; yet we drifted and floated down to Newport. We came to the wharf between 6 and 7. in the Evening.— We all finally concluded to remain on board the packet for the Night, and not to go on shore for lodgings— We walk’d however in the town part of the Evening.— The weather this day has been more like August than October— The heat of the Sun overpowering, and the sky perfectly serene.

13. Calm Night again; but this morning just before Sunrise the tide being in our favour, and a light breeze having sprung up we set Sail from Newport with the addition of one Passenger taken up there— A Quaker— The fair and easy breeze lasted us with some calm intervals untill we had pass’d point Judith, which we did about 11. in the morning. Soon after a fresh breeze arose West and by South—precisely the point of our course; against which we beat up untill the Night and through the Night— On its first appearance two vessels which had come out from Newport with us immediately tacked about and return’d— We continued as near to our course as we could.— This west-wind as Coll: Gibbs told me is a trade wind— Few vessels dare attempt to stem it.

14. After beating the whole Night against the wind, the tide sometimes favouring and sometimes opposing us, we found ourselves at Sun-rise this morning a-breast of New-London— The wind continued directly a-head all this day, excepting for a couple of hours towards Night, when it removed about three points— This was however of short duration. It soon return’d to its original position, and the breeze freshened untill the Sea became very heavy. We reached Falkner’s Islands about 3 in the afternoon— New-Haven soon after Sunset, and then cross’d the sound and beat to and fro upon the Long-island shore.— Our Packet, Eliza— Captn: Curry, owner, Captain J. Justin Master, roll’d and pitch’d so excessively great part of the day, and all the Night that most of our Company were sick.

15. I was up the whole Night, and the greater part of it upon deck— This morning the wind abated, and about noon became almost calm— We had reached Sanders’s point, the entrance of the East river— It was about four in the afternoon when we came to the passage of Hell gate, but the tide having turn’d about an hour before, we were obliged to anchor here for the Night— Some of our Passengers became so impatient of the delay that they went ashore in the boat, and undertook to find their way to New-York by land— Mr: and Mrs: Gamage, Mr: Prentiss and Mr: Butler went and lodg’d upon an island under which we anchor’d— Not more than five or six of us remained on board the Packet.

16. It was about 10. O’Clock this morning when we weigh’d anchor, and with the wind still a’head pass’d through Hell-gate and beat our way up to New-York; we landed at Crane-wharf about Noon. I went and engaged lodgings at Mrs: Anthony’s, N. 50. Broad-Street, and then return’d with a Carriage, and took up my wife and child, and the maid, Sarah Alexander— There is only one boarder in the house besides ourselves, a Mr: Hurdis of Providence— After dinner, I call’d at the Philadelphia Stage-Offices, where I found that Mr: Otis was gone on this morning, and that Mr: Quincy is now here.— I delivered two letters from Dr: Eliot and Dr: Holmes, to Dr: Miller, at his house N. 27. Dey Street, and had a couple of hours conversation with him— I call’d at the Mechanic Hall and afterwards at Mrs: Avery’s to see Mr: Quincy, whom I found at last— He left Boston on Monday, but had heard nothing of my boys— I call’d at Mr: King’s house, but he is in the Country, on Long-island, and expects to remain there untill December— I also was at Mr: M’Cormick’s but he was not at home— Mr: Rogers came to see us at our lodgings and invited us to dine with him in the Country to-morrow, which we however were obliged to decline.

17. Having nothing to do here, though on account of the child we were obliged to remain here, I spent the day chiefly in strolling about the Streets, but wrote letters to my father and to W. S. Shaw— Dr: Miller and Mr: M’Cormick called on me. This afternoon I walk’d on the battery, and saw the paper containing the signals of the merchants, by which they recognize their ships as they arrive. Mr: Piercy came this Evening with the model of his machine, for tanning leather, for which he is desirous of obtaining a patent— He explained its operation to me, but his model not being quite completed he took it away with him and is to bring it again to-morrow morning— I engaged seats for us in the Mail-pilot, which goes to-morrow morning at ten O’Clock.

18. At ten O’Clock this morning we cross’d the ferry at Powles Hoek, with a very boisterous wind, and immediately took the Mail-Pilot Stage— It was entirely full; the other passengers being (excepting one, a young Virginian,) members of Congress, going on to Washington— Among the rest were Mr: Knight of Rhode-island, and Mr: Thompson and Dr: Russell of New-York— There was also a newly elected member from New-Hampshire.— We dined at Elizabeth-Town, and stop’d for the Night at Brunswick— I stop’d at Gifford’s to leave a letter for Coll: Smith’s mother; but had not time to stay and pay her a visit— The weather in the morning was very warm, but in the afternoon and Evening became unusually cold.

19. Between 4 and 5. this morning we left Brunswick, with the Stage—breakfasted at Princeton—dined at Bristol, and arrived at Philadelphia about 7. in the Evening.— We endeavoured to get lodging’s at Richardet’s—Indian Queen, but he had not room for us: he went with us however, and not without difficulty succeeded in getting a place for us at Mrs: Clayton’s in the same 4th: South Street.— I went immediately down to the wharves, where the two lines of the Newcastle and Baltimore Packets lay, to enquire concerning a passage to-morrow morning; but I found nobody at the packet of the new line— On returning to our lodgings I found the child apparently very ill—
We sent immediately for a physician—the nearest in the neighbourhood, a Dr: Parke, who came and saw the child— He was however of opinion that its illness was only the temporary effect of riding so far in the cold of this day, which was severe for the season, and the too violent restoration of the circulations on its being suddenly brought from the air into a warm room.— The child after a time was composed, but the alarm and agitation upon its mother was so great that she in turn appeared at bed-time very ill.

20. My wife and child were both so well this morning that we were enabled to proceed upon our Journey. We took the new line of Newcastle and Baltimore packets, and at 1/2 past seven this morning embarked in the Diana— Captain Barnes— Calm and head-winds, blowing in light and momentary flows, the whole day— It was about 7. in the Evening when we arrived at Newcastle— We had a set of fellow passengers entirely new— Not one of the same Company with whom we came from New-York to Philadelphia.— Immediately upon landing at Newcastle we took the Stages for Cecil Court-House point, where we arrived at about 11. at Night— Here again we immediately embarked in the Packet Pinckney, Captain Taylor, and sailed with a fair wind for Baltimore.

21. We had an extremely boisterous and blustering Night— About one in the Morning the wind which had favoured us, only a couple of hours, came round between the West and Southwest; directly a-head, and after blowing very fresh untill about 3. struck the vessel with a sudden squall, which had almost overset her— The sea was running so high that it was impossible to carry sail, and the Captain ran in under the land, within a cove where we were sufficiently sheltered from the gale. Before we had come to anchor however the wind abated so much, that we stood out again into the bay and beat down about eight miles lower to Pool’s island; here we anchored just after day-break, and lay about three hours, after which we again got under weigh with two reefs in the sails— The wind continued a head but gradually abating untill we reached the North-Point, just at Noon— From thence up the river it was fair, and by half past one we were at the wharf in Baltimore— We dined at Evans’s tavern, the house being still kept by Stuart— After dinner we took a Hack and came out to Mr: Buchanan’s house, which is about four miles without the City.— On our way we saw the malefactors working on the road, in chains, with guards, armed attending on them at the side of the way— It was the first time I recollected ever to have seen this Spectacle; which is truly melancholy— Just at Sun-set we arrived at Mr: Buchanan’s, and found him and his family well— Mrs: Johnson is also here on a visit, of about three weeks, and returns with us to Washington.

22. We spent this day at Mr: Buchanan’s— His Sister, Mrs: Johnston, with her husband lately married, and Mr: Lawson Alexander, a Gentleman, whom I formerly knew in England, but had not seen since the year 1796. and did not again immediately recognize came out and dined there— I wrote a little in the forenoon.

23. Immediately after breakfast this morning, we all went into Baltimore, and resumed our chambers at Evans’s. At 2. in the afternoon we took a Hackney Coach again, and went out by the invitation of Mr: and Mrs: Johnston, to dine at Woodbine, the seat of Mr: Lloyd Buchanan, where they now reside; and which is about two miles without the City.— The company consisted of Mr: and Mrs: L. Buchanan, her mother and brother, named Stewart, Mrs: West, a daughter of S. Blodget at Washington, Mr: Lawson Alexander, and his brother Henry; with all our Company— We returned in the Evening to Baltimore, and Mr: & Mrs: A. Buchanan took leave of us— A Mr: Griffiths called upon us; and we found upon our return an invitation to tea at Mr: Harper’s, which we were however unable to accept.

24. At 8 this morning we took the Mail-Stage, and in company with Messrs: Stedman, Upham, Pitken & Barker, members of the house of Representatives, completed our Journey to Washington City, where we arrived just at the dusk of the Evening— Mrs: Johnson came with us— At the capitol-hill our fellow-travellers left us, and Mr: Eaton came into the Carriage, to go to Georgetown— He has just returned from attending on the trials of Mr: Burr, at Richmond. Our driver by much persuasion was prevailed upon to set us down at Mr: Hellen’s, where we found all the family, with Mr: and Mrs: Boyd, all well— And thus for the third time we have accomplished a long journey and voyage with an infant less than three months old— But Charles is a younger traveller than either of his brothers; since on our leaving Boston he was under eight weeks.

25. Heard Mr: Sayrs at Georgetown this morning; and afterwards paid visits to the President and to the Secretary of State— Mr: Jefferson was not at home— Mr: and Mrs: Cutts were at Mr: Madison’s— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd dined at Mr: Hellen’s with us— Genl: Mason of Georgetown and his Lady called there in the afternoon— I neither read nor wrote any thing, this day.

26. I called at the Secretary of State’s Office, and upon Dr: Thornton, with the models of Mr: Piercy, and his application for a patent;—which occasioned me to be late at the Capitol— I found the Senate assembled—twenty-four members present— The Vice-President in the Chair— They had just balloted for the members of a Committee to inform the President that the two houses were assembled; and ready to receive his Communications.— Mr: Anderson laid a motion on the table for consideration; the usual orders at the Commencement of the Session were pass’d, and the Senate might have adjourned about 1. O’Clock; but the House of Representatives being unusually delayed in their organization, and it being thought necessary to wait for the formal communications from them, the Vice-President left the Chair for a couple of hours, during which I went into the House— They were assembled in their new Apartment, in the South Wing of the Capitol— It is very elegant, but apparently very ill adapted to the purpose of debate— When I went in they were balloting for a Clerk. Genl: Varnum was in the chair as Speaker, and had been elected at the first ballot, without much competition— Mr: Macon the former Speaker, and Mr: Nicholas, who was also expected to have stood as a Candidate, being both absent— The candidates for the Office of Clerk were one Van Zant heretofore a subaltern in the late Clerk Beckley’s Office— Patrick Magruder, a member of the last Congress from Maryland, James Elliot, a member of the present Congress from Vermont, One King, and some scattering votes— There had been several ballots, and no majority— At the second ballot after I went in, Van Zant had 52 votes—59. would have given him the majority, and the place— It was certain for him at the next ballot; when Mr: John Randolph rose, and with a proper preface of apology, charged Van Zant with having listened at the door the Session before last, while the house were in Conclave, and divulged the speeches of members, made under the injunction and upon the trust of secrecy— Van Zant who was present applied in writing to the Speaker, for permission to be heard in his defence at the bar of the house, but was not indulged— Several motions were made to adjourn, to postpone the choice of Clerk untill to-morrow, &c. but without success— The balloting was renewed— Van Zant’s votes at the next ballot sunk from 52 to 16. and the next time Magruder was chosen— Untill the attack upon his competitor he had at no ballot received more than 36 votes— So that Mr: Randolph in substance made the Clerk.— The members were then sworn, and the usual orders of Communication pass’d— I returned to the Senate chamber, where after receiving the message from the House, we immediately adjourned— It was near 4. O’Clock— With my wife, and part of Mr: Hellen’s family I dined at Mr: Boyd’s—returned home early this Evening, but have not yet commenced my regular writing in my chamber.

27. I attended in Senate this morning at an hour sufficiently early— The President’s Message was received, and read, with the documents annexed to it— No other business was done and they adjourned before 1.— I went into the House, where they were balloting for door-keepers— They had just chosen Samuel Dunn, serjeant at Arms, instead of Wheaton who has held that office many years— The house adjourned early, and I spent the remainder of the day and Evening at home— Part of the family went to the Races— Mr: Sheldon pass’d the Evening with us below. This day I began writing in my chamber, both in the Morning and Evening; but from interruption could write but little— I sent several copies of the Message to Boston.

28. I moved two Resolutions in Senate for referring certain parts of the President’s Message to select Committees— Dr: Mitchill made a similar motion respecting another part— They all lie for consideration— Nothing else done— In the House they decided by yeas and nays to leave the appointment of their Committees still to the Speaker, and not appoint them by ballot—then adjourned— Our family went again to the Races— Genl: Van Cortlandt and Mr: Verplanck spent most of the Evening here.

29. The only thing done in Senate, was the choice of Dr: Gantt as chaplain— It was the third and last day of the Races— Mr: Hellen and myself dined at Mr: Boyd’s, with Mr:Forrest, Mr: Dick, Mr: Caldwell, Mr: Delany, and Mr: Ridgely— We also pass’d the Evening there—partly at cards— In the morning I called on Dr: Thornton, with Mr: Piercy’s Affidavit respecting his Patent, and wrote to Piercy himself.

30. The two Resolutions which I offered in Senate the day before yesterday were this day adopted and the subjects referred to select Committees—the first to five—Messrs: Smith of Maryland, Milledge, Mitchill and Anderson, with me—the other to a different Committee of three— I moved another resolution to add a new Rule to those we have for conducting business in Senate— A standing Committee to audit and controul the contingent Expences.— It lies for consideration— No other business was done, and we adjourned early— At home, I barely commenced the fair copy of my Lecture 27. and wrote not more than half a page— I employed the whole Evening in looking over the Journals of the Senate since I have been one of its members— In the numerous traces of my own conduct there I remark materials for serious reflection. Of the very little business which I have commenced during the four Sessions, at least three fourths has failed with circumstances of peculiar mortification— The very few instances in which I have succeeded have been always after an opposition of great obstinacy, often ludicrously contrasting with the insignificancy of the object in pursuit. More than one instance has occurr’d, where the same thing which I have assiduously laboured in vain to effect, has been afterwards accomplished by others without the least resistance; more than one where the pleasure of disappointing me has seemed to me the prominent principle of decision— Of the preparatory business matured in Committees I have had a share gradually increasing through the four Sessions, but always as a subordinate member— The merely laborious duties have been readily assigned to me, and as readily undertaken and discharged— My success has been more frequent the opposition than in carrying any proposition of my own, and I hope I have been instrumental in arresting many unadvised purposes and projects.— Though as to the general policy of the Country, I have been uniformly in a small, and constantly decreasing minority, my opinions and votes have been much oftener in unison with the Administration than with their opponents: and I have met with at least as much opposition from my party friends as from their adversaries— I believe, more— I know not that I have made any personal enemies, now in Senate; nor can I flatter myself with having acquired any personal friends— There have been hitherto two, Mr: Tracy and Mr: Plumer, upon whom I could rely, but it has pleased Providence to remove one of them by Death, and the changes of political party have removed the other— With the warmest wish to render real service to the public according to the measure of my ability, the path which Prudence prescribes to me under the circumstances of the time is to undertake little, to content myself with the regular attendance which is the duty of every member, and to restrain rather than indulge the propensities to debate.

31. The Senate having adjourned over to Monday, I pass’d this day entirely at home, excepting a quarter of an hour’s walk at the dusk of the Evening— I looked over my files of papers of the last Session, and wrote, a very little. Mr: and Mrs: Cranch were here this morning.

Day. The first ten days of the month we were making preparations for our Journey to this place— Then a fortnight in coming; and the week which we have spent here has not yet presented any regularity in the order of my occupations— I now rise usually between 7 and 8. Read or write untill near 10. Breakfast— Walk to the Capitol attend in Senate— Return home about 3. in the afternoon; write or read untill 4. Dine: and pass the Evening in company below, or abroad. I shall soon be more busy.
